Dear Methow Valley Students and Parents,

It’s with a heavy heart that I’m reaching out to inform you that our schools will be closed for all in-person and remote learning today, Tuesday, September 8th.

As you’re likely aware, the fires in Mansfield and Bridgeport have resulted in power outages, limited internet services, down phone lines, and unhealthy outdoor air quality. These conditions are compounded by WA DOH and CDC guidelines calling for the opening of windows and time spent outdoors.

We will be reassessing the conditions throughout the day with the plan to reopen remotely on Wednesday, September 9th and return to in-person instruction with Cohort B returning to school on Thursday, September 10th.

Meals are available today at each of our three Drop Zones (Winthrop Red Barn, TwispWorks, and Carlton Fire Station) between 12-1 pm.

Meals will be delivered to each bus stop during our am routes and to our three Drop Zones every Wednesday beginning tomorrow.

We miss you and can’t wait to see you!

The Methow Valley School District Selects David Mills to Serve as the New Liberty Bell Jr./Sr. High School Music Instructor!

David Mills has been selected to serve as Liberty Bell Jr./Sr. High School's new music instructor. David will be teaching concert band, jazz band, and offering a musical elective course driven in part by student interests.

A recent graduate of Western Washington University with a bachelor's degree in music education, David comes to us with a broad range of musical experiences and strong recommendations from his university professors and mentors. Originally from Aberdeen, Washington, he was an active member of the musical community playing in various groups including the Grays Harbor Symphony Orchestra. While concert music is his specialty, he also has expertise in musical theatre and jazz music.

When David isn’t working on a musical project he likes to spend time outdoors playing disc golf. He is very excited to make his way to the Methow Valley and join the Liberty Bell staff.

Please join us as we welcome new LBHS music instructor, David Mills!

Liberty Bell Girls XC Takes Top Honors in 2019-20 WIAA 2B Scholastic Cup

The Liberty Bell Girls XC team Athletic Teams received 1st place as a team in the 2019-20 WIAA 2B Scholastic Cup!

Combining all activities, Liberty Bell student-athletes placed 10th out of 66 schools in the 2B classification. This marks a 5th consecutive top ten finish for our Liberty Bell student-athletes... Grrr!

The WIAA Scholastic Cup recognizes performance in the classroom as well as on the playing surface. Schools that finish at the top of their respective classifications in state athletic competition receive points, as do schools that finish at the top in team academic performance.

Sportsmanship is also a factor, with substantial points deducted for ejections from contests. At the end of the year, the school with the most points in their classification is awarded the prestigious Scholastic Cup!

Please join us as we congratulate our coaches and student-athletes for their outstanding performance in the classroom and in their respective sports!

"Please let Mr. Whatley, know I'm wearing my tool belt and putting the skills I've learned to good use!" - David Kominak, LBHS Student

While our school facilities remain closed, learning continues, taking many forms...

This spring, LBHS student and standout baseball player, David Kominak has put down the glove and bat. In their place, he has strapped on his tool belt and is swinging a hammer in support of the local business community.

In spite of the many challenges faced by our students, families, and community, we continue to hear inspiring stories about caring, resilient, responsible, curious, creative students initiating action in support of their neighbors, local businesses, and service clubs by applying the knowledge and skills in their tool box (or tool belt) during this challenging period of time. All the while exercising social distancing measures of course!

We look forward to hearing about other examples of students who are finding meaningful ways to engage in authentic forms of learning!

Methow Valley students, you are the "pride" of the Methow Valley!

Jessica McCarthy has been appointed to serve as the Executive Secretary to the Superintendent. Jessica, a lifelong native of Okanogan County has lived in the Methow Valley for the past 13 years.

In addition to her time spent working for the Washington State Legislature and U.S. Congress, Jessica is a former small business owner and holds a Bachelor’s Degree in Accounting.

Jessica her husband Charlie have two young children who attend MVE. When she's not working or enjoying the outdoors, Jessica can be found sewing, baking, or creating something out of wood in their shop.

Traveling through space on an epic journey, co-piloted by 5th grade teachers, Mrs. Duguay and Ms. Miller, MVES 5th graders facilitated a culminating exhibition of their learning about the "Wonders of Earth and Space."

The exhibition was the conclusion of an integrated unit of inquiry-based study where students spent several weeks engaged in research process - asking questions, thinking critically about big ideas, accessing and analyzing multiple sources of information, developing important self-management skills, and preparing to communicate their new learning about earth and space with others.

Please join us as we celebrate the outstanding work displayed by our MVES 5th graders and thank you Mrs. Duguay and Ms. Miller for fostering the innate curiosity that resides within each of our students!

MVSD to Establish After-School Activities Bus

Working within the Strategic Area of Focus titled, "Equity and Excellence for All," the MVSD continues to make positive steps forward in its efforts to eliminate the barriers and obstacles faced by our students and families.

Last week, a team of building administrators, secretaries, and representatives from the MVSD Department of Transportation met, reviewed bus routes, ridership rates, staffing capacity, and student needs.

Balancing the safety of our students and drivers with the desire to ensure all students are able to access the many enriching after-school activities taking place throughout our community, they identified a solution. It was recommended that we establish an "After-School Activities Route."

Once implemented, the After-School Activities route will support students traveling to enriching activities, work or otherwise. Further, it will reduce the likelihood of overcrowding on our regular routes.

A big thanks to all involved... We look forward to sharing more about a timeline for implementing the new route soon.

October 3, 2019 at 4:20 PM ·

The Youth Arts Initiative (YAI) began in the Methow Valley School District #350 this week--YAY!

Administered by Methow Arts and funded by a pilot grant from Icicle Fund, the Youth Arts Initiative is a three-year pilot grant that has a goal of increasing the dosage of professional arts education, with a focus on sequential art learning at the younger grade levels to establish a foundation in the arts for later years.

Youth Arts Initiative instructor Anne Aageson Venable, who is employed by Methow Arts to deliver the YAI program, provided students with an opportunity to make relief prints based on patterns observed in nature. They learned about thin and thick lines, textures, patterns, as well as some of the vocabulary of printmaking.

Read more about YAI here: http://www.methowarts.org/youth-arts-initiative/

“Recognized schools are in the top 20 percent on multiple measures and are closing achievement gaps or have all student groups achieving at a high level,” said SBE chairman Kevin Laverty.

As stated in the MVSD's Strategic Vision, "We can't do it alone. We can do it together!" Please join us as we acknowledge our students, staff, parents, and many community partners for their collaborative efforts to develop curious, creative, competent, compassionate, action-oriented students prepared to pursue the widest range of post-secondary opportunities possible!

We Invest in What We Value - Our Students!

MVSD to Invest in Smaller Class Sizes, Adding a Third Grade Teacher in Fall of 2019-20 School Year!

Research and best practice suggests the relationship between the teacher and the student is the one of the most important factors contributing to a child's academic progress, social-emotional wellness, physical health, and future success, only to be exceeded by a "coherent system" reflecting these same attributes throughout the entire school from one classroom to another.

Committed to supporting strong relationships between the teacher, student, (and parents), MVES will be investing some of our limited resources into the addition of a third, 3rd grade teacher, beginning in the fall of the 2019-20 school.

Using projected enrollment figures, the additional 3rd grade classroom teaching position will lower class size averages in Kindergarten through 3rd grade to a ratio of less than 17 student per classroom teacher.

Thank you Methow Valley community for your generous support of our students!

shared_text:
Methow Arts
March 28, 2019 at 11:50 AM ·

"And That's Who I Am!" these collages proclaim.

Working with Methow Arts teaching artist Anne Aageson Venable, 5th graders at Methow Valley Elementary School explored their "Who We Are" International Baccalaureate unit through the lens of collage, creating display boards that feature photos, quotations, original poetry, and images that support their self-identity. First, they mixed paint to create appealing backdrops for their collage. Then, they spent several weeks writing poetry and collecting "strata"--the layers of images and text they would use to lay out an appealing display on the background. Finally, they experimented with different layouts, considering balance, unity, shape, space, color, and emphasis. Then they glossed the whole collages over with ModPodge for longevity.

Arts education sponsors in the Methow Valley School District #350 are: Methow Valley Fund of the Community Foundation of NCW, Public School Funding Alliance, Icicle Fund, the Robert B. McMillan Foundation, and Washington State Arts Commission. Thank you!

Animals of the Methow!

What is an ecosystem?
What are the needs of living things?
What are some of the threats to animal habitat?
How do animal adaptations help them survive?

These are just a few of the many questions Methow Valley Elementary 2nd graders have been exploring within their recent unit of study focused on animals and ecosystems of the Methow Valley.

During the unit of study, 2nd graders have been deeply engaged in research, applying their curiosity, critical thinking, communication, and organizational skills in an effort to make sense of the interdependency between animals of the Methow Valley and the ecosystem that we call home.

Please join us as we celebrate the exceptional work displayed by our second graders and acknowledge our outstanding staff, Methow Arts, the Public School Funding Alliance, and the many parent volunteers that make these enriching projects possible!

The Methow Valley School District invites you to register for the NCW 'Pathways to Prevention' Conference. Sponsored by the North Central Accountable Community of Health, the conference is scheduled to take place on Friday, March 15, from 9am-12pm at Liberty Bell.

Recognizing the key strategies to addressing substance abuse reside within our community, the conference is open to all who are interested in being a part of the conversation.

Our goals are to gain a deeper collective understanding of the many factors that influence substance abuse in the Methow Valley, increase knowledge of existing resources and gaps, and come away with prevention strategies that fit our community and its unique needs.

To register, please go to: https://ncw_opioid_response_conference.eventbrite.com

Please email Rachel Levi, MVSD Prevention Coordinator at rlevi@methow.org if you have any questions.
